‚ÄúWhen Walker Percy won the National Book Award, newsmen asked him why there were so many good Southern writers and he said, 'Because we lost the War.' He didn‚Äôt mean by that simply that a lost war makes good subject matter. What he was saying was that we have had our Fall. We have gone into the modern world with an inburnt knowledge of human limitations and with a sense of mystery which could not have developed in our first state of innocence‚Äîas it has not sufficiently developed in the rest of the country.‚Äù

     ‚Äî Flannery O‚ÄôConnor, ‚ÄúThe Regional Writer‚Äù

This is important, might as well repost it here since ZeroMe can't do that like other social media. From Firebox:

How to block a person on ZeroMe

    Find the public key of the person you want to block.
    Find the folder named after that public key in the hub folder.
    Go into that person's folder and look at data.json. Make sure that person is the right person you want to block.
    Delete all his or her files, including content.json. Then immediately make a content.json folder at the same place to prevent that file from showing up again.
    You cannot see that person's posts and comments anymore.

comment.body: @Talnicrom: thanks for the info
@Helloarch: gab is a freedom of expression, no censorship social network. But you have to get an invite to be able to make an account there. You can try asking for an invite @ https://gab.ai/
@Beard: dunno why, it's working on other browsers here though
@Helloarch: What if Gab was inside Zeronet?
anything on Twitch doesn't work on Firefox here
Dunno about you, but I can see on #ZeroMe what I post on #ZeroMePlus . I can't figure out your problem.
I don't know, it's working here. Try using a VPN, maybe it's blocked there in the country where you live.
@Sick Bird: me too, but I can't upload the video in 0, so...
Agreed. The LP was not about libertarianism. Was only about left-winged politics, since Gary started his campaign. He may well be the worst candidate that the LP supported.
@ZAlex: but ZeroMe Plus only blocks people in ZeroMe Plus, not other places in ZeroNet, I presume.
@Helloarch: where do you live? I'm from a socialist leftwing  playground for corrupt politicians called Brazil.
@Talnicrom: the "blocking" idea is exactly about hiding content from users I don't want to see. It's not like make them blocked for everyone else on 0net.
@Durand: there ain't such a thing as "sensible candidate". Weld is a crony corp supporter POS just like any of the others. Another socialist.
@Planteater: not really. Read about Hans-Herman Hoppe and you will understand.
@Darkneuron: except nazists, socialists and anyone else believing in politicians, that is.
@Bashrc: popular != profit
@Brkaka: mas sem a porta aberta para uploads, como vai distribuir o zite pelo Zeronet? √â o mesmo princ√≠pio do torrent.
@Riotpulv: jam
How much? I'm not fluent but I've studied japanese for 2 years, in a school.

@Flyman: I can read kana. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kana and a few kanji https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kanji , 20 or so. Kana is easy, kanji is very hard. I know basic words for colors and animals. You can try using a dictionary like http://jisho.org/ . Japanese people write them with a pen or a pencil :) just kidding, they have a sequence to follow, this is taught in schools and there are books about it, too, every character has a proper sequence of traces, basically. And "aka" ( Ëµ§ or „ÅÇ„Åã ) is "red" as a noum. "akai" ( Ëµ§ or „ÅÇ„Åã„ÅÑ ) is "red" as an adjective. "akari" ( Êòé or „ÅÇ„Åã„Çä ) means "bright". These are different kanji with a similar sound, but very different meanings. And first writing is in kanji (more commonplace) and the second one is in kana (can also be used, specially for kids who still didn't learn those kanji). Kanji is very hard and takes a lot of time to learn enough of them just to read a newspaper, I still can't read them. I use some OCR add-on like "perapera" for Firefox to read them for me and get their kana.

@Flyman: if you want to write japanese characters in a computer, you have to install an IME to do that. I recommend Google IME for that https://www.google.com/ime/ since it's available for more than one OS and is integrated with their search base, so you can try searching for the appropriated kanji, but it's only in japanese, you have to understand some japanese to understand the search. I even double-check the kanji with jisho.org or some other dictionary.
„Åå„Çì„Å∞„Å£„Å¶„Åè„Å†„Åï„ÅÑ„Çà„ÄÄ("good luck with that", in a free translation )
@Firebox: but everyone can do this to my zite?
@Firebox: I've cloned WikiEN, how do I get the private key for that? The FAQ I'm reading says I can only get that key if I created a zite from zero.

I didn't test it yet, but I got curious and found http://www.tagaini.net/ while searching about this. I'll test it later. There are lots of offline japanese dictionaries for iOS and Android, too, you may want to search for these on it's appropriate online store. I'll answer your other questions later if I can.

- So, "kana", as it was explained in that wikipedia article I've shown you (please, read it, it's good), is the japanese syllabic writing system. It's subdivided into "hiragana" and "katakana", yes. I just use the "kana" word because it's way shorter and still describes both systems altogether precisely. It's a japanese thing, so to speak.
- Ok, any IME integrated into the OS may be good enough to type in japanese, specially if you're offline. But Google IME can search for words while still typing it, and shows sentence and kanji examples. It's all up to what you want. I still like Google IME better.
- The „Çà particle indicates, among other things, an emphasis in this case, to get someone's attention. In the end of a sentence, it means something like "REALLY, good luck with that". Literally, the sentence means "REALLY, go for it!" or something like that. It's similar to the „Å≠ particle, which is used a lot in japanese. „Çà is also very common. You may use either one in this case, your choice.
- I`m not so sure of the akari kanji case, or other kanji, but I know this happens a lot, in either cases, sometimes I see sentences using just the kanji and others, the kanji and complementary kana. I'm not so sure, I'm gonna check it with other people fluent in japanese and I'll answer about it later.
@Erebus: is it private?
I know http://animetorrents.me/ , but it's not that good, compared to Bakabt.
I think my private key is gone, for some reason. I can't find it in 2 computers hosting the zite. Is there a way to generate another private key?
hello
@Firebox: so, I'm screwd, basically. :/ Thanks anyway. Well, shit happens. The Zeronet app crashed and I had to install it from zero. :/
Ok, Animebytes is private, and I can't get an invite. :/
@Flyman: ok, but I want to. I'm studying japanese. As someone said in my school: "it takes a whole life to study the japanese language".
@Flyman: about drawing kanji in a dictionary, if you use iOS, you can use the "Japanese" app. I use that, it's very useful.

- ok, never mind about iOS. I guess there might be good japanese dictionaries for android/windows phone, too, but I'm not sure. I just use iOS. that's what I know, and I know the "japanese" app is iOS only.
- Just remember that japanese is a language formed with other costumes from another country. So, words will have to be adapted to our comprehension. Maybe it's the same for russian, I guess, I don't know any russian. In "konnichiwa", it really means like that because the japanese people say "konnichiwa" to each other starting from 10AM. Before 10AM, it is "ohayougozaimasu". Some people translate "konnichiwa" like "good afternoon", but it's not entirely correct since it starts at 10AM. It's some japanese people's costume, it works for the japanese this way, I don't know why. Always remember: "another language to learn means to learn new costumes and cultures together". Also, the „ÅØ particle is one of the hard to understand cases in japanese, but yes, „ÅØ (ha) can be pronounced like (wa) in some cases. And konnichiwa can be written in both forms, both are correct, but ‰ªäÊó•„ÅØ is more formal and more common. ‰ªäÊó•„Çè is rare and not formal, from what I know.
- I promise I'll check that book later and I'll tell you later what I think.
- first kanji part is "mahou" (magic). second part I can't figure out, my dictionary points it as a personal name, "Kakuto" or "Shouto". I got the kanji, "to fly"+"person", but I can't quite figure out. "a flying person's magic". Anyway, remember I'm not fluent, I'm learning japanese, too.
@Henur: maybe in japanese, too.
I think there's a way to convert kindle DRM ebooks to mobi format, no?
@Flyman: yeah, that sucks. Another reason I like to buy some games on GOG.
@meidan: I wish I was fluent in japanese for that, I only know just the basics, can't even formulate a single sentence. :/
@Avon: only animetorrents.to and nyaa.eu , and nyaa is not private.
@Erebus: ok, so I just need to find an invite for AnimeBytes. I'm gonna try IRC. Cyberbegging for the win.

@Erebus: I swear, I'm using avistaz, animetorrents and bakabt and my ratio on all of the three is good, I really keep up the upload and I don't cheat. As for the email, you can send it to kosherx@hmamail.com , that's safe enough for me. (I'm not cheating, it's just that its some really nice secure email)
@Militaryriotlab: no, and it seems a fine tune. But I'm not up to date with Macross since Macross Plus. After that, I know nothing about Macross.
Basically, politics.
